mdx.rawBody:
---
status: public
observed: "research"
shortDescription: "Running a Scratch program first resets the state of the world and then executes the program"
shortCorrection: "Running a Scratch program executes the program starting with the world in its current state"
concepts:
  - Variable
  - Lifetime
related:
  - id: ResetStateEachLoopIteration
    relation: Different case for reset
inOtherPl:
# - pl: Java
#   id: ElseAlwaysExecutes
# - pl: Python
#   id: ElseAlwaysExecutes
spec:
  - id: scratch3.0
    sections: ["wiki-When_Green_Flag_Clicked_(block)"]
plVersion:
# from: jls8
# to: jls14
expressibleInNms:
# - id: ControlFlowAsGraph
#   how: graph of a loop
references:
  - citationKey: hartmannProgrammingConceptsMisconceptions2022
    phenomena: ["n3"]
---

All Scratch program executions start from a fixed starting state,
with variables set to their initial values,
and with the sprites in their initial position and facing in their initial direction.

childMdx.rawBody:
Running a scratch program (pressing the green flag button)
will start executing the program from whatever state the world is in right then.
The values of variables and the state of the sprites
will not implicitly get reset by starting the program.

Assume the following script:

<ScratchBlocksMDX>
{`
when green flag clicked
move (100) steps
change size by [10]
change [score v] by (1)
`}
</ScratchBlocksMDX>

If the user executes this script,
the sprite moves forward 100 steps from its current position,
increases its size by 10 from its current size, and
increments the score variable by 1 from its current value.

Note that running the program will **not** reset the state of the sprites
or the values of variables.
The world will start in whatever state it is when the flag button was clicked.
Thus, the start state of the world
depends on previous runs of the program and on direct manipulations by the user.

If starting a program is supposed to start from a well-defined state,
the scripts need to explicitly set that state
(set variables as well as the position/heading/... of sprites to specific values).

The cause of this misconception might lie in a belief
that a given block of the script will always have the exact same effect.

### Empirical Evidence This misconception appears in **Item P9** in the [Scratch ProMAT](/reference/hartmannProgrammingConceptsMisconceptions2022) assessment: #### Question Here you see a program with a loop. {` when green flag clicked repeat (2) turn cw (90) degrees   end `} At the beginning, the cat is facing right. When we run the program once, the cat faces left. Where will the cat be facing if we run the entire program twice? #### Answers The answers are displayed as the cat sprite facing the four cardinal directions:

The fact that for most programming languages each program execution
starts from a blank slate
could be seen as just a consequence
of equating program executions with operating system processes.
In most programming languages,
each time we execute a program we create an entirely new process
(with completely cleared out memory),
which means there is no available prior program state.

A student with this misconception might simply not be familiar
with this prevalent but somewhat arcane approach to implementing systems.
In fact, modern application frameworks provide means to persist and restore
the state of an application across executions
(e.g., when restarting a web browser,
the new process will open all the previously open tabs,
to provide the user with a smooth experience).

This misconception could occur not just in Scratch,
but also in other programming languages like Smalltalk, Pharo, or Self,
and, more generally, in "live programming" environments,
where the program state persists beyond the developer-triggered execution of code.

frontmatter.shortDescription: Running a Scratch program first resets the state of the world and then executes the program
frontmatter.shortCorrection: Running a Scratch program executes the program starting with the world in its current state

phenomenonKinds.name: Mistakes
phenomenonKinds.description: Misunderstandings, type errors, other semantic errors

phenomena.name: Confusing the assignment operator with the comparison operator
Confusing "short-circuit" evaluators with conventional logical operators
Using keywords as method or variable names
Forgetting parentheses after a method call

frontmatter.subjects: 542 hand-drawn expression trees from 12 exams in 6 university courses

phenomenonKinds.name: Diagram mistakes
phenomenonKinds.description: Mistakes in student-drawn expression trees, related to structure, types, or values

phenomena.name: A literal is inlined into the parent node
A simple variable access or field access is inlined into the parent node
The target (expression before dot) has been inlined (e.g., into a method invocation or a field access with explicit targets).
The index in an array access expression has been inlined.
Token 'new' is kept in separate node, which possibly includes a hole for connection.
Binary operator that is left-to-right associative is treated as right-to-left associative.
The tree is primarily a chain, reflecting, in order (e.g., left to right -> top to bottom) the constructs of the source code.
A node is replaced with a subtree containing code that appears inside methods or constructors called by the expression.
An *implicit* this is explicitly reported in the expression tree.
Access to the length field of an array is represented with extra parentheses.
A method / constructor with no arguments is represented in the tree with its proper name but without parentheses.
Missing token 'new' in a class, interface, or array instance creation.
A literal is missing the type annotation.
A simple variable access is missing the type annotation.
The type of the node is not the actual type of the node, but rather the type specified for the surrounding 'hole'.
The type of a character literal node is String.
A literal is missing the value annotation.
A simple variable access is missing the value annotation.
String value reported without quotes.
Both branches of a conditional expression are annotated with values.

phenomena.name: Function calls alias variables
Function calls copy data structures
Variable definitions alias variables
Variable definitions copy structures recursively
Data structures might refer to variables by their references
Storing data structures into data structures makes copies
Expressions are only evaluated when their values are needed
